newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Eight survivors of KAL crash airlifted to Seoul.
newsitem.headline: Eight survivors of KAL crash airlifted to Seoul.

text.p: Eight people who miraculously survived the fiery crash of a Korean Air Lines jumbo jet on Guam were airlifted to Seoul on Friday, witnesses said.

The eight were lowered on stretchers from a U.S. medical evacuation plane to eight ambulances which sped them to hospital for treatment of injuries they suffered when Flight 801 slammed into a hillside on the Pacific island on Wednesday.
U.S. military medical personnel accompanied seven South Koreans and a Korean-born American who were in good enough state to travel to Seoul, airport officials said.

The military evacuation plane, C-9 Nightingale, is due to fly back to Guam to ferry 11 more South Korean survivors home, Seoul officials said. Most survivors suffered burns from a fire that broke out after the crash, KAL officials said.
U.S. officials said only 27 of 254 people aboard survived the crash. Five other people were alive when they were pulled from the smouldering wreckage, but died later in hospital.
Rescuers have given up hope of finding any more survivors amid the wreckage.

"I felt like I was dying in each second of waiting amid conflicting news reports that my son died or survived," said the mother of Lee Yong-ho, one of the airlifed survivor, as she waited in a Seoul hospital for his son.
"I felt as if my blood was drying up," she said.
U.S. safety investigators who searched through wreckage of the KAL jumbo jetliner said on Thursday it was too early to determine what caused the crash.

"It is really too early to speculate the cause of this accident," George Black, a member of the National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) and chairman of the committee investigating the crash, said.
The flight data and voice recorders arrived in Washington on Wednesday night and work on deciphering the information began immediately, according to a spokesman for the NTSB.
